Description: A small Bes-jar of coarse red siltware pottery, with a blunt pointed base and convex sides. The narrow mouth is surrounded by a short, cylindrical neck, which was finished with a slightly flared rim. The rim has been broken and all the original top edge is missing. The coarse fabric shows voids from burned-out straw. On the exterior is a red slip, worn off in places. The side of the vase is decorated with a very abbreviated Bes-face, formed of applied blobs of clay for the ears and eyes, the latter set in a slight depression.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Dafana, Findspot 52 W (west?), south-eastern quarter of the Saite enclosure (so-called "Camp"), area of ironsmith's workshops.
Curator's comments: The Findspot number 52 W is pencilled on the side of the vase.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 64, 65 § 61, pl. xxxv, 64)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.97, p.106, p.194, pl.36, p.218, pl.60)
